content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 3 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would consider the potential outcomes strategically. In this game, both 'R' and 'B' have disadvantages: if I pick R when my opponent picks B, I get nothing while they get 40$. On the other hand, if I pick B when my opponent picks R, I also get nothing while they get 40$.

However, there is a strategy that guarantees a positive return regardless of the opponent's choice: if I pick 'R' and my opponent picks 'B', I earn 40$ in round one. Then, since my opponent knows I picked R in round one and wants to maximize their own payoff, they would choose B in round two, earning 20$. In round three, knowing that my opponent chose B in round two, I can safely pick B as well, earning another 20$.

So, the total payoff for this strategy is 40$ + 20$ + 20$ = 80$. On the other hand, if I choose 'B' first, my opponent can exploit my choice and earn more. Therefore, I would choose R as my strategy in this game to maximize my earnings.

So, my choice would be {R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Since we both picked 'R' in the first round, our payoffs were 45$ each. Now, let's consider the second round.

Knowing that I chose R in the first round, my opponent would pick B in the second round because it guarantees them a payoff of 20$. If I choose R again, I will get nothing in the second round since my opponent picked B. But if I switch to B this time, I'll get 40$ in the second round while my opponent gets 20$.

However, if I switch to B and my opponent sticks with R, they would get 45$ (since that was their initial strategy), and I would get 20$. Since neither of us has a guaranteed advantage in this scenario, it's best to stick with the strategy that offers the best payoff in the long run: B.

So, my choice for the second round would be {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

Since we both picked 'B' in the second round, our payoffs were 20$ each. Now, let's consider the third and final round.

Knowing that I picked B in the second round, my opponent would stick with their strategy and also pick B in the third round since it guarantees them a payoff of 20$. If I choose R this time, I will get nothing in the third round since my opponent picked B. But if I stick with B as well, I'll get another 20$, completing the game with a total payoff of 40$ (20$ + 20$).

If I switch to R now, I would get 45$ in the third round since my opponent stuck with their initial strategy and picked B. But I would have missed out on earning 20$ in the second round. Sticking with the strategy that offers the best payoff in the long run is still 'B'.

So, my choice for the third and final round would be {B}.
